Introduction

Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, is a chronic, inflammatory skin condition that usually begins in early childhood.  It commonly presents with acute exacerbations of dry, pruritic patches in a characteristic distribution depending on age (eg, flexural creases in older children and adults).  Diagnosis is clinical, and management includes skin hydration (eg, liberal emollients) and topical corticosteroids.

Pathogenesis



The pathogenesis of eczema is multifactorial and includes a permeable skin barrier, exposure to environmental irritants, and immune dysfunction.



  • Permeable skin barrier:  Loss-of-function mutations in filaggrin, an epidermal protein that helps maintain the skin barrier, result in decreased barrier integrity through impaired keratin filament aggregation and decreased tight junction expression.  Genetic defects in other epidermal proteins or lipids may also result in increased permeability and loss of water content.
  • Environmental triggers:  Cutaneous exposure to environmental allergens/irritants (eg, scented soaps/detergents), excessive bathing, low humidity, or excessive heat in a patient with a dysfunctional skin barrier can trigger an inflammatory cascade.
  • Immune dysfunction:  An exaggerated Th2-predominant immune response promotes IL-4 and IL-13 cytokine release, which stimulates IgE production and allergen sensitization.


The combination of these factors results in the intense pruritus and characteristic rash of eczema.

Pathology



Histologic findings demonstrate nonspecific inflammation that depends on the chronicity of the lesion.



  • Acute disease reveals epidermal spongiosis (ie, intercellular edema) (
    image 1
    ), with a dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate consisting of T cells, eosinophils, and partially degranulated mast cells.
  • Chronic disease is characterized by epidermal hyperplasia and hyperkeratosis; macrophages dominate the dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate.

Risk factors



The greatest risk factor for the development of eczema is a family history of atopy, or the genetic tendency to have an exaggerated IgE response to allergens.  The classic atopic triad includes:



  • Eczema
  • Asthma
  • Allergic rhinitis

Clinical presentation



Eczema typically presents at age <5, with many patients developing symptoms in infancy, but adult-onset disease can occur.  The rash is characteristically dry and intensely pruritic, with morphology and distribution dependent on patient age (

figure 1
).



  • Young children (age 0-2):  Recurrent acute flares of ill-defined erythematous/hyperpigmented patches, papules, vesicles, or scales are located on the face (
    image 2
    ), trunk (
    image 3
    ), and extensor surfaces of the extremities; the diaper area is classically spared.  Excoriations secondary to scratching are often present.
  • Older children (age >2):  Acute lesions consisting of dry, erythematous patches are most commonly found in the flexural creases (eg, antecubital/popliteal fossae) (
    image 4
    ).  Repetitive, chronic scratching can lead to lichenification (
    image 5
    ), and affected areas may have both acute and chronic features.
  • Adults:  Acute and chronic lesions continue to be found in the flexural creases, with additional involvement of the hands, feet, and eyelids (
    image 6
    ).


Clinical variants of eczema can occur with or without a history of classic atopic dermatitis findings:



  • Nummular eczema (
    image 7
    ):  round, pruritic, scaly plaques, most commonly on the extremities.  It is also referred to as discoid eczema due to its characteristic coin shape.
  • Dyshidrotic eczema (
    image 8
    ):  pruritic, vesicular rash that primarily affects the palms, soles, and sides of the digits.

Diagnosis



Eczema is a clinical diagnosis based on chronic or relapsing pruritus with typical morphology and age-specific patterns.  The diagnosis is supported by early age of onset and a family history of atopy.  Affected patients usually have high serum IgE levels and peripheral eosinophilia, but these findings are not required for diagnosis.

Differential diagnosis



  • Contact dermatitis (
    image 9
    ):  intensely pruritic and erythematous patches and a vesicobullous eruption isolated to regions exposed to allergens; it is rarely widespread.  Symptoms typically resolve within weeks of allergen/irritant avoidance.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis (
    image 10
    ):  yellow, greasy scales of the face (eg, eyebrows, nasolabial folds, retroauricular areas) and scalp; infants (
    figure 2
    ) can additionally have confluent erythema of intertriginous areas (eg, neck folds, axillae, diaper region).  The extremities are typically spared, and pruritus is mild if present.
  • Psoriasis (
    image 1
    ):  erythematous, well-demarcated papules and plaques with a thick, silvery scale involving the knees, elbows, scalp, and lower back.
  • Scabies (
    image 12
    ):  intensely pruritic, excoriated papules in the finger webs, wrists, axillae, and genitalia.  When left untreated, the rash progressively spreads and does not follow an intermittent course.
  • Tinea corporis (
    image 13
    ):  pruritic, scaly, annular patches that respond to topical antifungal treatment.

Management



The mainstay of eczema management includes avoidance of factors that contribute to itching, such as excessively hot or dry environments and harsh soaps and detergents.  Regular use of emollients to maintain skin hydration can relieve pruritus.



Acute eczema flares are treated with topical corticosteroids, which act primarily by inhibiting transcription of genes encoding inflammatory mediators.  Low-potency agents (eg, hydrocortisone) may be adequate for mild symptoms, whereas more significant symptoms may warrant moderate- to high-potency corticosteroids (eg, triamcinolone, betamethasone).



The duration of topical corticosteroid use is usually limited to 2 weeks per flare because chronic daily use can cause cutaneous atrophy due to the inhibition of epidermal keratinocyte proliferation and fibroblast function.  For areas with thinner skin prone to atrophy (eg, eyelids), calcineurin inhibitors (eg, tacrolimus) can be used and work by inhibiting T-cell signaling that would normally lead to transcription of the proinflammatory cytokine IL-2.



Severe eczema may require ultraviolet phototherapy or systemic immunosuppressive therapy (eg, biologics, cyclosporine, JAK inhibitors).  Dupilimab, an IL-4 and IL-13 receptor antagonist, has a favorable safety profile and is the preferred long-term treatment for refractory eczema.

Prognosis



Eczema follows a chronic course during early childhood with periodic flares triggered by environmental factors.  Its severity tends to lessen with age and, in most cases, atopic dermatitis resolves by adulthood.



An earlier onset of atopic dermatitis (eg, infancy) is associated with a greater risk for developing other atopic conditions, including allergic rhinitis, asthma, and food allergies.  A compromised skin barrier facilitates allergen penetration (eg, from food) and subsequent sensitization, facilitating the development of food-induced urticaria and anaphylaxis.

Complications



Breaks in the skin barrier from eczematous inflammation and/or excoriations increase the risk of infection.



  • Impetigo (
    image 14
    ):  Almost all patients with eczema are colonized with Staphylococcus aureus, and secondary infection can occur due to a defective epidermal barrier.  Impetigo presents with papules or pustules that progress to weeping, honey-crusted lesions.  Management is with topical or oral antibiotic therapy.
  • Eczema herpeticum (
    image 15
    ):  Herpes simplex virus infection (either primary or reactivated) associated with underlying atopic dermatitis.  Painful, monomorphic vesicles on an erythematous base evolve into punched-out erosions, most commonly involving the face, neck, and trunk; disseminated and potentially fatal disease can occur.  Management is with systemic acyclovir therapy.

Summary



Atopic dermatitis (ie, eczema) (

) is an atopic skin disorder caused by epidermal barrier dysfunction and inflammation.  Acute manifestations include dry, pruritic patches, whereas chronic disease presents as lichenification from repeated scratching; secondary infection (eg, impetigo) is a common complication.  Management includes avoidance of environmental triggers and regular use of emollients, and topical corticosteroids are often used to treat acute flares.  Eczema follows a chronic course during early childhood, and most cases resolve by adulthood.
